summary: This document is an email from Chris Dilorio forwarding a series of messages alleging widespread financial fraud, money laundering, and SEC corruption related to companies like FTE Networks, Parallax Health Sciences, and others. It references legal judgments, SEC actions, and connections between various individuals and entities, accusing regulators of facilitating ongoing criminal schemes. This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. DiIorio to various legal and regulatory bodies, primarily alleging massive, ongoing securities fraud, money laundering, and criminal obstruction by the SEC and other entities. The author details interconnected schemes involving penny stock shells, illegal naked short selling, and specific companies like Riot Blockchain, Virtu Financial, and Aegis Capital, while accusing SEC officials of protecting criminal enterprises.

persons.name: Chris Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the email chain, alleging massive financial fraud, SEC corruption, and money laundering in multiple companies. Presents himself as a whistleblower.

persons.name: Jed S. Rakoff
persons.context: Signed a stipulated order and final judgment in a case involving defendants and residential property agreements, referenced as part of the legal backdrop.

persons.name: Alex Szkaradek
persons.role: CEO of Vision Property Management / Convicted Felon
persons.context: Named as a defendant in a New York lawsuit for predatory practices and involved in FTE Networks acquisitions. Described as a convicted NY felon.

persons.name: Antoni Szkaradek
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Alex Szkaradek in the $350 million acquisition of Vision Property Management by FTE Networks.

persons.name: Eliot Kang
persons.role: CEO/Managing Partner of Inmost Partners LLC
persons.context: Linked to Inmost Partners LLC, which acquired over $50 million in prior issued notes related to FTE Networks.

persons.name: Michael Beys
persons.role: CEO of FTE Networks / Former EDNY Prosecutor
persons.context: Described as the current CEO of FTE Networks, controlling Cobblestone Ventures LLC, and a former federal prosecutor.

persons.name: Letitia James
persons.context: Filed a lawsuit against Vision Property Management and Alex Szkaradek for alleged predatory lending practices.

persons.name: Linda A. Lacewell
persons.role: New York Superintendent of Financial Services
persons.context: Co-filed the lawsuit against Vision Property Management with AG Letitia James.

persons.name: Mary Kay Vyskocil
persons.context: Issued an opinion and order dismissing a derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks executives and board members.

persons.name: Ephraim Barenbaum
persons.context: Brought a derivative action on behalf of FTE Networks against executives and board members for corporate misconduct.

persons.name: Fred Sacramone
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks, motion to dismiss granted.

persons.name: James Shiah
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks, motion to dismiss granted.

persons.name: Jeanne Kingsley
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks, motion to dismiss granted.

persons.name: Stephen Berini
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks, motion to dismiss granted.

persons.name: Brad Mitchell
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks, motion to dismiss granted.

persons.name: Christopher Ferguson
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks, motion to dismiss granted.

persons.name: Luisa Ingargiola
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks, motion to dismiss granted.

persons.name: Patrick O'Hare
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks, motion to dismiss granted.

persons.name: Lynn Martin
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks, motion to dismiss granted.

persons.name: Kevin Goodman
persons.context: Referenced as the SEC official involved in the Parallax COVID-19 disclosure complaint and overseeing FINRA.

persons.name: Paul Arena
persons.context: Charged by the SEC for misleading COVID-19 disclosures, described as involved in multiple money laundering shells.

persons.name: Nathaniel Bradley
persons.context: Charged by the SEC alongside Paul Arena for misleading COVID-19 disclosures.

persons.name: Keith Coulston
persons.context: Linked to Ionic Ventures and Ironridge, described as prolific 'bag men' in money laundering schemes.

persons.name: Michael Sobeck
persons.context: Named as a selling shareholder in Parallax, previously involved with Tangiers and other shells.

persons.name: Christina Avila
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Michael Sobeck in Harbor Gates Capital, based in Puerto Rico.

persons.name: Richard Rosenblum
persons.context: Involved in Innovative Payment Solutions (IPSI) and linked to other money laundering shells.

persons.name: David Stefansky
persons.context: Linked to Aquamed Technologies/Nexgel and involved with Richard Rosenblum.

persons.name: Nachum Stein
persons.context: Controlled Aquamed/Nexgel with David Stefansky.

persons.name: Robert Klimov
persons.context: Investor in IPSI and involved in Black Cactus Global Inc., linked to paid pump-and-dump schemes.

persons.name: Milton Ault
persons.role: Controller of DPW Holdings / Ault Group
persons.context: Controls DPW Holdings, parent of Digital Power Lending, which was a seller in Parallax.

persons.name: Michael Wachs
persons.context: Investor in DPW Holdings, linked to Net Element and other schemes.

persons.name: Ofer Abarbanel
persons.context: Named in an SEC complaint for transferring approximately $102 million from investors into NARL accounts.

persons.name: Nicholas Abbate
persons.role: COO of State Funds/New York Alaska
persons.context: Former market maker at Knight Capital, COO of the fund that received $102 million in investor funds.

persons.name: Mathis Schultz
persons.context: Founder of Northern Data in 2015, mentioned in the context of the company's ownership and operations.

persons.name: Chad Everett Harris
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to the construction and sale of the Whinstone data center in Texas by Northern Data/Northern Bitcoin.

persons.name: Christopher J. DiIorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of securities fraud, money laundering, and SEC corruption related to Knight Capital, Virtu Financial, Riot Blockchain, and other entities.

persons.name: Dougie Cifu
persons.context: Accused of knowingly lying about Virtu Financial's equity market making share volumes on an earnings call to conceal illegal activity.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.role: Alleged money launderer, subject of SEC action
persons.context: Named in an SEC action for microcap stock fraud; connected to multiple shell companies like NewLead, FreeSeas, and Inergetics.

persons.name: John M. Fife
persons.context: Charged by the SEC for acquiring and selling billions of penny stock shares without registering as a dealer; connected to Chicago Venture Partners and Iliad Research.

persons.name: Justin W. Keener
persons.role: Alleged unregistered penny stock dealer (JMJ Financial)
persons.context: Charged by the SEC for operating as an unregistered penny stock dealer.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Central figure accused of controlling multiple money laundering shell companies, including those that became Riot Blockchain (Aspenbio/Venaxis/Bioptix), MGT Capital, and Inergetics.

persons.name: Mr. Gottschall
persons.context: SEC official accused of conducting a grossly inadequate investigation into Riot Blockchain and issuing a 'no further action' letter without proper due diligence.

persons.name: Mark B. Fisher
persons.role: Owner of MBF Clearing Corp and MBF Capital
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to a fraud 'acquisition' of a trading platform by Riot Blockchain, with entities based in New York and possibly Miami.

persons.name: Dmitry Akhanov
persons.role: CEO of Rusnano USA Inc., former head of Russian Federal Energy Agency
persons.context: Named as an insider in Bioptix/Alphasniffer (precursor to Riot Blockchain), raising national security concerns due to Russian government ties.

persons.name: Robert Eide
persons.context: Mentioned in FINRA and SEC disciplinary proceedings related to Aegis Capital, which is accused of being a prolific money launderer.

persons.name: Brian Colleran
persons.context: Healthcare executive who paid to resolve False Claims Act allegations; became a large shareholder in the Honig-controlled shell company Millenium Biotech/Inergetics.

persons.name: Chad Readler
persons.role: Former DOJ prosecutor, now Federal Judge
persons.context: Was the prosecutor on the Brian Colleran civil fraud case; later appointed as a federal judge by President Trump.

persons.name: Eric Bustilloe
persons.context: Accused by the author of being a 'grossly corrupt Piece of Shit' on par with other corrupt SEC officials.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.role: Trump PA Campaign Manager, NITE Board Member
persons.context: Described as a 'Not So Independent Board Member' of NITE/Virtu and involved with his own alleged money laundering shell, FSD Pharma.

persons.name: Scott Shay
persons.context: Mentioned as chairman of Signature Bank, which served as an escrow agent for alleged fraud offerings and has ties to Trump/Kushner.

persons.name: Ivanka Trump
persons.role: Former Board Member of Signature Bank
persons.context: Noted as a former board member of Signature Bank (SBNY), which is implicated in alleged fraud offerings.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Subject of a sentencing by Judge Cote which the author calls a 'gross miscarriage of justice,' alleging he was set up by Handler/Ressler (Ares Management).

persons.name: Jason Sunstein
persons.role: CFO of multiple alleged money laundering shells
persons.context: San Diego resident and CFO of several OTC Pink sheet companies (Viper Networks, Santeon Group) alleged to be money laundering shells.

persons.name: Ashraf Rofail
persons.context: CEO of Santeon Group, another alleged money laundering shell company.

connections.description: Co-involved in the $350 million acquisition of Vision Property Management by FTE Networks, receiving common stock, promissory notes, and Series I preferred shares.
Alex Szkaradek issued a fraud note to Cobblestone Ventures LLC, which is controlled by Michael Beys, the CEO of FTE Networks.
Eliot Kang's Inmost Partners LLC acquired more than $50 million in prior issued notes related to FTE Networks through various assignments.
Both charged by the SEC for misleading COVID-19 disclosures related to Parallax Health Sciences.
Kevin Goodman is an SEC official made Chief Overlord of FINRA, overseeing the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.
Both involved in Harborview Advisors and connected through money laundering shells like Aquamed Technologies/Nexgel.
Klimov/Bellridge Capital is an investor in IPSI, where Rosenblum is involved.
Michael Wachs's Esousa is an investor in Milton Ault's DPW Holdings.
Abarbanel transferred $102 million in investor funds to accounts where Abbate was COO of the receiving fund.
Chad Everett Harris was chosen by Mathis Schultz to build the large data center in Rockdale, Texas for Northern Data/Whinstone.
Honig is alleged to have controlled the money laundering shells (Aspenbio/Venaxis/Bioptix) that 'pivoted' to become Riot Blockchain.
Both are alleged prolific 'Bag Men' involved in interconnected money laundering schemes and SEC frauds, with Sason showing up as a holder in Honig's shell Inergetics.
Cifu is the CEO of Virtu Financial, which owns the market maker NITE, which is accused of being the core criminal enterprise facilitating illegal naked shorting.
DiIorio is a whistleblower who has submitted multiple TCRs (Tip, Complaint, Referrals) and alleges the SEC is criminally obstructing his claims and protecting the entities he reported.
Signature Bank acted as the escrow agent for the Bioptix private placement offering that gave Honig et al. ownership in what became Riot Blockchain.
Robert Eide is the CEO of Aegis Capital, a firm accused of being a prolific money launderer for OTCM/NASDAQ shells.
Akhanov, head of Rusnano USA with Russian government ties, is listed as an insider in Bioptix/Alphasniffer, a precursor to Riot Blockchain.
After his healthcare fraud, Colleran became a large shareholder in Millenium Biotech, a shell company controlled by Barry Honig.
SEC official Gottschall terminated an investigation into Riot Blockchain without, according to the author, conducting a proper investigation or visiting its alleged headquarters.

events.title: Stipulated Order and Final Judgment Signed
events.description: Judge Jed S. Rakoff signs a stipulated order and final judgment in a case involving defendants and residential property agreements, ordering restitution and injunctions.

events.title: Dismissal of FTE Networks Derivative Lawsuit
events.description: Judge Mary Kay Vyskocil dismisses with prejudice a derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks executives and board members for failure to allege demand futility.

events.title: FTE Acquires Vision Property Management
events.description: FTE Networks acquires US Home Rentals/Vision Property Management for $350 million from Alex and Antoni Szkaradek.

events.title: SEC Charges Parallax for COVID-19 Disclosures
events.description: The SEC charges Parallax Health Sciences, Paul Arena, and Nathaniel Bradley for misleading COVID-19 disclosures, described as a fraudulent complaint.

events.title: Riot Blockchain Acquires Whinstone Data Center
events.description: Riot Blockchain acquires the Whinstone US data center in Rockdale, Texas from Northern Data AG.

events.title: Northern Data/Northern Bitcoin buys Whinstone
events.description: Northern Data/Northern Bitcoin purchased the Whinstone data center.

events.title: Northern Data sells Whinstone Texas Data Center
events.description: Northern Data sold the Whinstone Texas data center.

events.title: Virtu Financial Q1 2021 Earnings Call
events.description: CEO Dougie Cifu made statements about April equity market making volumes being 'a hair under 10 billion shares per day,' which the author alleges is a knowing lie to conceal much higher volumes from illegal naked shorting.

events.title: SEC Ends Investigation into Riot Blockchain
events.description: SEC official Mr. Gottschall issued a letter terminating the investigation into Riot Blockchain without recommending enforcement action.

events.title: SEC Charges Joshua Sason et al.
events.description: SEC filed charges against Joshua Sason and others for an elaborate microcap stock fraud, an action the author claims was based on his information.

events.title: SEC Charges John M. Fife et al.
events.description: SEC charged John M. Fife and companies he controls for acting as an unregistered securities dealer involving billions of penny stock shares.

events.title: SEC Charges Justin W. Keener
events.description: SEC charged Justin W. Keener (JMJ Financial) for operating as an unregistered penny stock dealer.

events.title: Author's Field Trip to Riot Blockchain Address
events.description: Christopher DiIorio visited the listed address of Riot Blockchain in Castle Rock, CO, and found it did not house the company but rather an ISP and a Pakistani BPO entity.

locations: Rockdale, Texas (location of Whinstone data center)
Castle Rock, Colorado (listed world HQ of Riot Blockchain, alleged to be non-existent)
7961 Shaffer Parkway Suite 5, Littleton, CO (address of Vista Gold VGZ, another alleged shell)
202 6th Street, Suite 401, Castle Rock, CO (Riot Blockchain SEC filing address)
40 Wall Street, New York (listed office for Joshua Sason entities)
Miami, Florida (mentioned in relation to Mark B. Fisher and SEC Director Eric Bustilloe)
San Diego, California (base for alleged shell companies and SEC LA office)
Tel Aviv, Israel (address for SciSparc Ltd, formerly Therapix)
Boulder, Colorado (former base for Bioptix Diagnostics)
keyFacts: Chris Dilorio alleges the SEC is a 'grossly corrupt, criminal organization' actively facilitating massive frauds and money laundering through shell companies like FTE Networks and Parallax Health Sciences.

FTE Networks transformed from a telecom infrastructure company to a major single-family home rental operator, acquiring Vision Property Management for $350 million from convicted felon Alex Szkaradek and Antoni Szkaradek.

The SEC charged Parallax Health Sciences executives Paul Arena and Nathaniel Bradley for misleading COVID-19 disclosures, but Dilorio claims the complaint omits key players and is part of a broader cover-up.

Dilorio references a $102 million transfer by Ofer Abarbanel to accounts controlled by Nicholas Abbate's fund, alleging the SEC complaint omitted connections to Brown Brothers Harriman and Mosaic Financial.
Northern Data AG, founded by Mathis Schultz, sold its Texas data center to Riot Blockchain and holds a 12% stake in RIOT, with the center built by entrepreneur Chad Everett Harris.

The author, Christopher J. DiIorio, alleges the SEC is engaged in massive, ongoing criminal obstruction and corruption, actively facilitating frauds on the public while denying him whistleblower awards.

Riot Blockchain is presented as a prime example: a 'money laundering shell' with Russian ties (via Dmitry Akhanov/Rusnano) that only exists in SEC filings, having evolved from Honig-controlled shells like Aspenbio, Venaxis, and Bioptix.

Virtu Financial (VIRT) and its market maker NITE are accused of being the core criminal enterprise, deriving 80-90% of equity market making volume from illegal naked shorting of OTC shells to facilitate money laundering.

Multiple SEC enforcement actions (against Joshua Sason, John Fife, Justin Keener) are claimed to be based on the author's information but have not been posted to the SEC's whistleblower award-eligible website, which he cites as evidence of obstruction.

The document alleges deep interconnectedness between alleged fraudsters (Honig, Sason), compromised SEC officials (Gottschall, Bustilloe), complicit financial institutions (Signature Bank, Aegis Capital), and political figures (Trump associates, appointed judges).
